coreCitation.title: U.S. Census Median Home Value Change in Boston
coreCitation.briefDescription: Median home value change aggregated to the census tract level; geography covers the City of Boston; time period covers 2006-2010 and 2014-2018 as five year averages
coreCitation.fullNotes: This data represents median home value change in Boston. The data originates from the United States Census Bureau's American Community Survey. The Census Bureau has aggregated individual survey responses to census tract geographies. The LMEC worked with cartographer Daniel Huffman to process the census data. We created a new dataset from the census data to study the change of housing value in Boston. The geography covers the City of Boston. The time coverage compares changes between 2006-2010 and 2014-2018, each as five-year averages.
coreCitation.briefGenealogy:
1. We downloaded statistics about median home value from a census data download tool 
 2. We also downloaded census tract GIS boundary files from the same tool 
 3. We edited the data tables to only include important information about the topic of study 
 4. We renamed columns with human-readable column headers 
 5. We documented the new names in a codebook 
 6. We combined the new data tables to the GIS boundary files using GIS software to create the final dataset
coreCitation.accessCondition: This dataset is in the public domain. There are no restrictions on use.

temporal.temporalNotes: This project compares census data from the 2006-2010 and 2014-2018 American Community Survey estimates.

representation.healthCheckQualifier:
The Census Bureau's ACS Design & Methodology Report details the process by which survey questions were first developed and how stakeholders were initially included in that process.  
 
 The Census Bureau does not make documentation available on the topic of ongoing plans for inclusion of the voices of those represented by and most impacted by the survey.

publicResponsibility.healthCheckQualifier:
The Census Bureau publishes healthy technical documentation on methodologies used to anonymize and aggregate data by geography. The documentation includes notes about how the Census Bureau understands the mandatory nature of the Census, and reasons why the data is beneficial to society. 
 
 There is no available documentation on any known privacy issues or methods taken to ensure all participants understand how their data will be used.

historicContext.healthCheckQualifier: The documentation does not reflect on the ways the data program is at risk for repeating past harms. It does not describe the ways in which U.S. census data collection has considered its relationship and contribution to systemic injustice.

methodology.healthCheckQualifier:
The Census Bureau's ACS Design and Methodology Report provides extremely healthy documentation about the technical methdologies used to produce the survey data. 
 
 Census annual budgets are public and easily discoverable, but materials explaining how the funding process works geared towards citizens could be more easily available.

potentialImpact.healthCheckQualifier:
There is healthy documentation about potential positive impact and future funding dependent on this data program. 
 
 There is not very much easily discoverable documentation about potential negative impact, especially if there are existing factors which should be flagged to avoid harm. The documentation could state more clearly how the data should and should not be used, with clearer remarks about known limitations.

publishedWorks.title: Change in median housing value, 2010 to 2018
publishedWorks.author: Huffman, Daniel P.
publishedWorks.publisher: Boston Public Library. Norman B. Leventhal Map and Education Center

codebooks.title: Renamed Fields Dictionary
codebooks.notes: Cartographer Daniel Huffman provided a codebook for how they renamed fields when cleaning this dataset.

ingredients.notes: This census tract geography data was joined to census statistical demographic data
This statistical census demographic data was joined to census tract geography data
